confusion_pairs.title: Fail-open vs Fail-closed

a.definition: If the security device fails, traffic continues to flow (availability wins, security visibility/control may drop).

b.definition: If the device fails, traffic is blocked (security wins, availability may drop).

bullets: Fail-open preserves business continuity but can create an unprotected window.
Fail-closed preserves enforcement but can cause outages if the device is a chokepoint.
Choose based on business impact: which failure hurts more—downtime or reduced security?
Inline devices may support fail-open bypass, but not all failures trigger it.

confusion_pairs.title: Air gap vs VLAN segmentation

a.definition: No network path exists between systems; data movement requires physical transfer.

b.definition: Software-defined separation of broadcast domains on shared switching infrastructure.

bullets: Air gaps stop remote access by design; VLANs still rely on correct configs and enforcement.
Air gaps raise operational friction; VLANs scale and are easier to manage.
VLAN attacks target misconfigurations (e.g., trunking/VLAN hopping); air gaps are bypassed via removable media.
Use air gaps for 'cannot ever leak' zones; use VLANs for most enterprise segmentation.

confusion_pairs.title: SDN vs SD-WAN

a.definition: Centralized software control of network behavior (usually inside a datacenter/campus) via controllers.

b.definition: Software-defined overlay for wide-area connectivity that can blend MPLS/4G/5G/broadband with policy-based routing.

bullets: SDN is about controlling switching/routing inside a network; SD-WAN is about stitching sites together efficiently.
SDN often drives micro-segmentation and dynamic policy; SD-WAN drives path selection and resilience across links.
SD-WAN is a common building block inside SASE deployments.

confusion_pairs.title: SASE vs Traditional VPN

a.definition: A cloud-delivered model combining SD-WAN + secure access (e.g., ZTNA/Zero Trust) + security services (firewall, CASB, etc.).

b.definition: Creates an encrypted tunnel to a trusted network; typically focuses on transport rather than full security stack.

bullets: VPN gives connectivity; SASE gives connectivity + policy enforcement + security inspection at scale.
SASE aims to secure users/devices wherever they are, not just when they 'dial in'.
VPNs can be part of SASE, but SASE adds identity-aware policy and cloud security controls.

confusion_pairs.title: IPSec VPN vs TLS (SSL) VPN

a.definition: Layer 3 VPN using IPSec; supports tunnel/transport modes and is common for site-to-site and broader traffic types.

b.definition: VPN that uses TLS; can be portal-based (browser) or full tunnel, often easier for remote access without heavy client config.

bullets: IPSec is great for network-layer tunneling; TLS VPN is great for user/app access and clientless portals.
TLS VPNs can segment access per application more granularly; IPSec often feels like 'you are on the network'.
On exams and in the wild, 'SSL VPN' usually means modern TLS.

confusion_pairs.title: Full-tunnel vs Split-tunnel VPN

a.definition: All traffic goes through the VPN tunnel, including general Internet traffic.

b.definition: Only traffic destined for the remote trusted network goes through the VPN; other traffic goes directly to the Internet.

bullets: Full tunnel improves security/monitoring but increases bandwidth load on the VPN site.
Split tunnel reduces bandwidth cost but exposes non-corporate traffic to untrusted networks and reduces visibility.
Coffee-shop Wi‑Fi + split tunnel is a classic 'leak my traffic' combo.

confusion_pairs.title: IDS vs IPS

a.definition: Detects suspicious traffic/behavior and alerts; typically passive (tap/SPAN) and cannot block.

b.definition: Detects and actively blocks/controls traffic; must be inline to stop packets.

bullets: Inline placement enables prevention but introduces a potential point of failure.
Passive monitoring avoids outages but only gives visibility and alerts.
Both can be signature-based or anomaly-based; prevention is the differentiator.

confusion_pairs.title: NGFW vs UTM

a.definition: Next-generation firewall with deep inspection and app awareness (Layer 7 features) in addition to Layer 4 controls.

b.definition: Unified threat management: an all-in-one security box (firewall + IDS/IPS + filtering + more), often aimed at simpler deployments.

bullets: NGFW is often higher throughput and more specialized; UTM is broader and more 'out-of-box'.
UTM is common in small/mid orgs; NGFW often needs more tuning and expertise.
Markets blur, but exam intent: NGFW = app-aware firewalling; UTM = combined security suite.

confusion_pairs.title: Forward proxy vs Reverse proxy

a.definition: Sits in front of clients; forwards client requests to servers, can anonymize and enforce outbound policy.

b.definition: Sits in front of servers; receives client requests and forwards to backend servers, often for caching/load balancing.

bullets: Forward proxy = controls users going out; reverse proxy = protects and scales services coming in.
Forward proxies help with web filtering and egress control; reverse proxies help with performance and shielding origin servers.
Both can cache and apply policy—direction of who they represent is the key.

confusion_pairs.title: DNSSEC vs DNS filtering

a.definition: Authenticates DNS data using digital signatures to prevent tampering (integrity/origin), not confidentiality.

b.definition: Blocks/redirects queries to known-bad domains using blocklists, reputation feeds, and policy rules.

bullets: DNSSEC answers 'is this DNS answer authentic?'; DNS filtering answers 'should we allow this domain?'
DNSSEC can stop poisoning; DNS filtering can stop users reaching phishing/malware domains quickly.
They complement each other—different problems.

confusion_pairs.title: Domain hijacking vs DNS poisoning

a.definition: Attacker takes control of a domain’s registration/account and changes records at the source.

b.definition: Attacker injects false DNS answers so victims resolve a domain to attacker-controlled IPs.

bullets: Hijacking changes the truth at the registrar/authoritative source; poisoning tricks resolvers/caches about the truth.
Hijacking affects everyone resolving the domain; poisoning may affect only specific networks/caches.
DNSSEC helps against poisoning; registrar security controls help against hijacking.

confusion_pairs.title: Network ACLs vs Firewall rules

a.definition: Permit/deny rules on network devices (routers/switches/cloud VPCs) controlling traffic flows, often stateless and order-based.

b.definition: Policy rules on a firewall appliance/host that may be stateful, application-aware, and tied to security zones.

bullets: ACLs are a blunt traffic filter; firewalls are a more complete security control (often stateful).
ACLs commonly live 'inside' network fabric; firewalls commonly live at trust boundaries/DMZ edges.
Both are rule lists—context (state/app awareness/placement) is what changes their power.

network.attack_surface.rule: Attack surface = every place an attacker can touch: services, ports, management interfaces, exposed features.
network.attack_surface.micro_example: You scan your public IPs and list open ports + admin panels. That list is your external attack surface.

network.security_zones.rule: Security zones separate trust/sensitivity levels; crossing zones should force controls and logging.
network.security_zones.micro_example: DMZ web server zone is isolated from the internal database zone with firewall rules in between.

network.device_placement.rule: Where you place devices (border, DC edge, between VLANs) decides what they can see and protect.
network.device_placement.micro_example: Put an IPS inline at the DC border to block inbound exploits; put sensors on taps for visibility.

network.connectivity.rule: Connectivity planning is security planning: redundancy, provider features, medium, and path diversity matter.
network.connectivity.micro_example: Two different ISPs on physically separate paths prevents a single fiber cut taking you offline.

network.failure_modes.fail_open.rule: Fail-open means 'keep traffic flowing' when the device dies—great for uptime, risky for enforcement.
network.failure_modes.fail_open.micro_example: Inline IPS power failure → bypass engages → traffic flows but you lose prevention/inspection.

network.failure_modes.fail_closed.rule: Fail-closed means 'block traffic' when the device dies—great for control, brutal for availability.
network.failure_modes.fail_closed.micro_example: Firewall crash → no packets pass → business outage, but nothing sneaks through uninspected.

network.physical_isolation.air_gap.rule: Air gap = no network link. It’s the nuclear option for stopping remote access.
network.physical_isolation.air_gap.micro_example: A classified workstation has zero network cables/Wi‑Fi. Data moves only via approved removable media.

network.logical_segmentation.vlan.rule: VLANs segment at Layer 2 using tags; security depends on correct configuration and enforcement.
network.logical_segmentation.vlan.micro_example: Guest Wi‑Fi VLAN can’t reach the internal admin VLAN; traffic must cross a firewall/router with rules.

network.high_availability.rule: High availability designs remove single points of failure and allow maintenance without downtime.
network.high_availability.micro_example: Two web servers behind a load balancer keep the site up during patching or a node failure.

network.sdn.rule: SDN centralizes control of network behavior; it can enable dynamic segmentation and quarantine.
network.sdn.micro_example: Controller detects a risky device and pushes a rule to isolate it into a quarantine segment.

network.sdwan.rule: SD-WAN uses overlays + policy routing across WAN links to improve resilience and control cost.
network.sdwan.micro_example: Video calls use the lowest-latency link; bulk backups use cheaper broadband overnight.

network.sase.rule: SASE = cloud-delivered secure access: SD-WAN + Zero Trust + security services for users anywhere.
network.sase.micro_example: Remote users connect to nearest SASE PoP; web traffic is inspected and policy-enforced in the cloud.

network.segmentation.rule: Segmentation limits blast radius: compromise one zone, don’t get the whole kingdom.
network.segmentation.micro_example: HR workstations can’t talk to finance databases except through a specific app gateway.

network.screened_subnet.dmz.rule: A screened subnet (DMZ) hosts less-trusted, Internet-facing services while shielding the private network.
network.screened_subnet.dmz.micro_example: Public web server sits in DMZ; only HTTP/HTTPS inbound and only DB port outbound to internal DB.

network.traffic.east_west.rule: East‑west traffic = lateral traffic inside the datacenter; treat it as untrusted in Zero Trust designs.
network.traffic.east_west.micro_example: A compromised app server tries to reach other servers laterally—microsegmentation blocks it.

zero_trust.overview.rule: Zero Trust assumes no implicit trust: verify every request continuously using identity + device + context.
zero_trust.overview.micro_example: User logs in from a new country on an unmanaged laptop → extra MFA or access denied.

zero_trust.control_plane.rule: Control plane = the brains: adaptive identity, threat scope reduction, policy decisions and execution.
zero_trust.control_plane.micro_example: Policy Engine checks SIEM + IAM + device posture; Policy Admin issues a session token or kills the session.

zero_trust.data_plane.rule: Data plane = where traffic flows: subjects/systems access resources through enforcement points and zones.
zero_trust.data_plane.micro_example: A device’s request passes through a Policy Enforcement Point before it can reach the enterprise resource.

network.nac.rule: NAC decides who gets on the network and where they land (normal VLAN vs quarantine) based on posture/policy.
network.nac.micro_example: Unpatched laptop connects → NAC drops it into remediation VLAN until updates + AV are compliant.

network.8021x_eap.rule: 802.1X is port-based authentication using EAP—no creds, no network access.
network.8021x_eap.micro_example: A switch port stays 'unauthorized' until the supplicant authenticates via RADIUS using EAP.

network.port_security.rule: Port security limits MAC addresses per switch port to reduce spoofing and CAM table overflow shenanigans.
network.port_security.micro_example: User port allows 1 MAC; plugging a rogue switch with many devices triggers a violation and shuts the port.

network.stp_loop_prevention.rule: Loop prevention (STP/BPDU protections) stops Layer 2 loops from melting your network into a broadcast storm.
network.stp_loop_prevention.micro_example: Someone plugs both ends of a cable into switches → STP blocks one port to break the loop.

network.dhcp_snooping.rule: DHCP snooping blocks rogue DHCP servers and can validate DHCP message integrity on switch ports.
network.dhcp_snooping.micro_example: Attacker runs DHCP server on a user port → switch drops offers because only uplink is 'trusted'.

vpn.ipsec.rule: IPSec is a suite for encrypting/authenticating IP traffic; commonly used for site-to-site VPN tunnels.
vpn.ipsec.micro_example: Branch router builds an IPSec tunnel to HQ so internal subnets route securely over the Internet.

vpn.tls_vpn.rule: TLS VPNs secure access using TLS; can be clientless portals or full tunnels and often allow app-level segmentation.
vpn.tls_vpn.micro_example: User hits a web portal, authenticates, and accesses internal apps without a full network-layer tunnel.

vpn.tunnel.full.rule: Full-tunnel sends everything through VPN: more security visibility, more bandwidth/latency cost.
vpn.tunnel.full.micro_example: Remote laptop routes all Internet browsing via corporate proxy through the VPN for inspection.

vpn.tunnel.split.rule: Split-tunnel sends only corporate-destined traffic through VPN: saves bandwidth, leaks visibility and raises risk.
vpn.tunnel.split.micro_example: Teams traffic goes through VPN, but general web browsing goes direct—untrusted Wi‑Fi can sniff metadata.

appliance.jump_server.rule: Jump servers (jump boxes) are hardened, monitored stepping-stones for admin access across zones.
appliance.jump_server.micro_example: Admins RDP/SSH into the jump box, then manage servers in a restricted management VLAN with full audit logs.

appliance.load_balancer.rule: Load balancers spread traffic across servers for performance and availability; algorithms matter.
appliance.load_balancer.micro_example: Round-robin for simplicity; least-connection when session load varies; sticky sessions when state is local.

appliance.proxy.rule: Proxies relay requests and can filter, cache, and enforce policy—know whether they represent clients or servers.
appliance.proxy.micro_example: A forward proxy blocks gambling sites for users; a reverse proxy fronts web servers and caches static content.

appliance.web_filter.rule: Web filters block/allow by URL/content category/reputation, via centralized proxy or endpoint agents.
appliance.web_filter.micro_example: Marketing can access social media; everyone else gets blocked by category rule + reputation feed.

appliance.dlp.rule: DLP watches for sensitive data leaving controlled boundaries and can block, alert, or force encryption.
appliance.dlp.micro_example: User tries emailing a file with credit card numbers → gateway blocks and notifies security.

appliance.ids_ips.rule: IDS alerts; IPS blocks. Placement (tap vs inline) decides whether you can prevent or only detect.
appliance.ids_ips.micro_example: Passive sensor sees exploit attempts; inline IPS drops the malicious packets before they reach the server.

firewall.types.rule: Firewall type choice changes what you can stop: packet filters vs stateful vs app-aware NGFW vs WAF/UTM.
firewall.types.micro_example: A WAF blocks SQLi patterns; an NGFW spots risky app traffic on allowed ports; UTM bundles many controls.

firewall.rules.rule: Firewall rules are explicit allow/deny decisions by source/destination/protocol/port—default-deny beats wishful thinking.
firewall.rules.micro_example: ALLOW TCP 443 to DMZ web server; DENY all other inbound. Log denies for investigation.

network.acl.rule: ACLs are ordered permit/deny rules on network devices and cloud networks—fast, blunt, and easy to misorder.
network.acl.micro_example: Rule 10 allow SSH to admin subnet; Rule 30 deny ICMP from Internet; later rules never match if earlier matches.

deception.honeypot_honeynet.rule: Honeypots/honeynets lure attackers into monitored traps so you can learn their tools and paths.
deception.honeypot_honeynet.micro_example: A fake vulnerable SSH server logs every command an attacker types and every file they drop.

deception.honeyfile_honeytoken.rule: Honeyfiles/honeytokens are tripwires: if accessed or exfiltrated, assume breach and investigate hard.
deception.honeyfile_honeytoken.micro_example: A 'Payroll_2026.xlsx' honeyfile is opened; the alert fires because only attackers should touch it.

management.out_of_band.rule: Out-of-band management keeps admin interfaces off the regular data network—attackers can’t easily reach them.
management.out_of_band.micro_example: Switch console is only reachable from a management VLAN via a jump server, not from user VLANs.

dns.security_dnssec.rule: DNSSEC authenticates DNS answers with signatures so clients can detect tampering/poisoning.
dns.security_dnssec.micro_example: Resolver verifies the signed DNS record chain before trusting the IP for a banking domain.

dns.filtering.rule: DNS filtering blocks known-bad domains fast, often by returning a safe redirect instead of the real IP.
dns.filtering.micro_example: User clicks phishing link → DNS filter returns internal warning page instead of attacker site.

email.security_spf_dkim_dmarc.rule: SPF says who may send, DKIM proves a message wasn’t altered, DMARC tells receivers what to do when checks fail.
email.security_spf_dkim_dmarc.micro_example: DMARC policy set to quarantine: emails failing SPF/DKIM land in spam; reports help tune before reject.

tls.ephemeral_pfs.rule: Use ephemeral keys in TLS to get perfect forward secrecy: one stolen key shouldn't unlock past sessions.
tls.ephemeral_pfs.micro_example: Attacker later steals a server key, but past TLS sessions stay safe because each session used unique ephemeral keys.

monitoring.snmp_traps.rule: SNMP traps are device-to-manager alerts triggered by events (link down, auth failure, restarts, etc.).
monitoring.snmp_traps.micro_example: Router interface goes down → it sends a linkDown trap so monitoring can alert the on-call team.

monitoring.file_integrity.rule: File integrity monitoring detects unexpected changes to critical files—great signal, noisy if poorly tuned.
monitoring.file_integrity.micro_example: Tripwire flags a changed /etc/ssh/sshd_config outside of patch windows → investigate for tampering.

attacks.on_path_ssl_stripping.rule: On-path attacks reroute traffic through the attacker; SSL stripping downgrades HTTPS protection to read/alter data.
attacks.on_path_ssl_stripping.micro_example: Rogue Wi‑Fi AP intercepts the initial HTTP request and keeps the victim on HTTP to steal session cookies.

attacks.dns.rule: DNS attacks include domain hijacking, poisoning/cache poisoning, and URL redirection via hosts file tricks.
attacks.dns.micro_example: Victim resolves a real domain to attacker IP due to poisoned cache, or registrar account takeover changes records.

attacks.credential_replay.rule: Credential replay reuses captured auth material (hashes/tokens) to impersonate a user—encryption + session IDs reduce it.
attacks.credential_replay.micro_example: Attacker captures a session token and replays it; modern defenses bind tokens to TLS/session/device context.

attacks.ddos.rule: DDoS overwhelms a target using many sources; reflected/amplified attacks weaponize legitimate services.
attacks.ddos.micro_example: Spoofed DNS query triggers large replies to the victim (reflection + amplification) until the link saturates.
